Any idea what change spacex made to go from most landings failing to most succeding? I am an aero space machininst work on large air, and spacecraft parts. Largest in California. After watching one of the last failed landings before any good ones I sent an unofficial message through the "grapevine" to an executive employee at spacex that they should increase roll control authority on landing. Suggested increasing the power of RCS if needed. After that most landings were good.

a booster comes back black and white because it produces a lots of drag in upper layer of the atmosphere and the booster cannot survive in such conditions .So,the booster makes a re-entry burn and the fire or soot touches or hits the booster repeatedly which makes it black.

When I was growing up in the early 1960s, maybe age 10 or so, it was said many years later that us kids who liked rockets had a "Phallic" psychological disorder.  I never believed that.  As a 10-year-old kid, I used to make believe my dad's car had missiles on it that I could shoot at other cars.  After all, he did drive a 1959 Chevy (Cat Eye) Impala with the wings on the back and the front had what looked like rocket tubes for headlights. It was a perfect space ship for a kid.  What was a 10-year-old kid who watched "Flash Gorden" every afternoon supposed to think, especially when his hormones were raging?

Amazing video! Just one small correction. The soot is a result of incomplete combustion, pyrolysis only occurs when there is no burning, just heat.
The key difference is that the first generates heat and usually requires an oxidizer, while pyrolysis uses up heat and only involves the decomposing of the original chemical. The ablative black tiles unerneath the space shuttle, for example, are designed to pyrolize upon reentry to use up the heat that would have otherwise started heating up the shuttle interior.

So, the rocket takes off into space. As it gains speed it flies a great distance away from the launch pad, vertically and laterally. It then, somehow, turns around, so at some point it is in effect stationary, and then accelerates back towards the area above the launch pad. It then starts to fall in freefall. These boosters heigh 15 tonnes empty so to prevent them from hitting the ground at 2,000mph you would think that the rocket would have be running upon  re entry and all of the way down to a point where it is moving slowly enough to land. And also it lands the same way up as the launch. The chances of this being fake is 100%. watch the videos and you will see that Thunderbirds had better special effect. Pathetic, amateur fakery.

So a simple question turned into a 14 minute video. Rockets get extremely hot traveling up through the atmosphere, but the reason a SpaceX rocket turns black is probably because as it comes down the thrusters are fired to slow it down and position it. The constant ignition of the rockets produces soot from unburnt fuel and since it's travelling down, the soot coats all the way up the rocket.

Thought: machining a custom textured surface, through etching or cutting, on the lower section of the boosters skin might reduce or eliminate the 'soot'.
The vertical micro channeling of the surface texturing could be designed to encourage gravity assisted migration of condensation from the upper & on to the lower section of the booster .
This area would inturn ice up and shed the layers as it built up.
Proper design could help resist adhesion between the textured lower booster surface & built up ice sheets or water.
Soot that typically would cling to the boosters surface would be shed through ablation.
Just a thought. ~ KiwiKev

I could be wrong, but I believe the soot isn’t so much actually from the rocket engine nozzles. It’s more likely from the open cycle turbine exhaust as it runs an off stoich mix to keep the turbo pump turbine from melting. Fuel rich, off stoich means cooler and very sooty! Also it doesn’t get thrown far from the rocket. It more trickles out the bottom compared to the main nozzles.

Not only Space X but all rockets with LOx on board like the Atlas,shiny stainless steel before LOx loading, pure white after loading. The Saturn 5 added another twist, no other rocker ever has, insulate the liquid Hydrogen tanks,stage 2&3, on the inside. Not only to keep the liquid from boiling off but to keep air on the outside from liquefying which would increase heat transfer to the LH2 an order of magnitude and hense boil off losses. If the Space Shuttle had done this the foam would not have been needed and the Columbia accident would not have happened. NASA does not learn from their lessons including continuing to use man killing solid rockets as on their new SLS. Hopefully Space X will put them out of the launch business with their all liquid rockets,smart.

Hi Tim, at 7:55, you mentioned that the Minotaur rocket's "banana skin" is there to prevent boil off during fuel up. According to Wikipedia, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minotaur_I Minotaur I, the version shown in the video, has 4 solid propellant stages. Solid rocket propellants are preloaded during manufacturing, I don't think there's fuel up or boiling off associated with this type of launch vehicle. But I do believe the "banana skin" has something to do with temperature control or humidity control. If you can please verify I am correct or not, it will be greatly appreciated! The sootyness shows just how rich they run the rockets. If combustion was complete then there would be no soot, but would also run so hot that the rockets might melt.

Most of the soot comes from one specific part of the exhaust -- namely from the exhaust of the turbopumps, which we can see here at 4:41.


The column of black smoke is coming from the turbine exhaust, on the side of the main nozzle. It is very visible is in the videos and photographs of the ground tests of the Merlin engines: "Merlin 1D Engine Flight Qualification Test"



The video "Tom Mueller (SpaceX) Explains The Merlin Rocket Engine" answers why the turbine exhaust is so sooty.

Why SpaceX don't wash the landed rocket?

Great video, two tiny corrections, kerosene is jet fuel. Same thing. RP-1 is a more highly refined form of petroleum than kerosene and eliminates many impurities like sulfur which would be bad for the engines. Both are basically diesel but higher grades. All of them are made from petroleum however the distillation temperature will yield diesel, kerosene, RP-1 or any number of products.
And the soot actually doesn't come from the exhaust plume of the engines. Those burn extremely clean. Because it's combusted at high pressures with pure oxygen there is almost no soot left, even if the engine runs fuel rich, most of that will burn up once it leaves the nozzle. You can observe this very well with the high speed footage of Saturn V. A black band of material exits the engines with a flame front climbing up towards the engines, never reaching them.

The soot comes from the gas generators that drives the turbopump. Here the combustion is extremely fuel rich and only partial leaving a lot of soot. It's the small flame vents next to the engine nozzles where a slow moving flame can be observed. It's easily observable on the BFR announcement where he stands in front of booster. This is what provides the soot. If they where staged combustion kerosene engines like RD-180 there wouldn't be much soot. That's why BFR will be pretty shiny after reentry, no major soot because of different fuel, and staged combustion engines that will burn the bit of soot that methane could make.

The engine actually runs very cleanly, no significant soot at all.  It’s the turbopump gas generator that produces tones of soot.  The gas generator exhaust is to the side of the engine and it runs longer than the engine itself.  The gas generator runs very rich to keep the turbine temperature from getting too hot so there is a lot of under burned sooty exhaust being expelled.

Actually your current electric car (at least currently) has an exhaust pipe. It's that big chimney from that coal-powered power plant a couple of hundred miles away. That of course will hopefully change in the future when we, and I truly hope we make that breakthrough, create a working fusion power reactor. The other sources of course are renewables. However, as for now, the base load is still provided by very dirty coal powered or more clean, but also radioactive waste producing nuclear power plants.
